sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Handwritten letter from Maximilian Harden to Schenker, undated [probably October or November 1894]
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: Harden casts aspersions on Hermann Bahr. — Advises that he probably won't have room to publish one of Schenker's articles, but requests that Schenker send it for his review.
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: Eigenschaften; characteristics; Empfindung; sensibility; Leidenschaft; passion; Routine; Artikel; article; Lessing; Shakespeare

tei:opener.tei:salute: Sehr geehrter Herr,This letter is undated. From the references to Hermann Bahr, it may be datable to October or November 1894.

tei:div.tei:p:
Minnas Zofe sagt daß man am liebsten von den Eigenschaften spricht, die man nicht hat.Minna is the title character in Gotthold Ephraim Lessing's 1767 comedy Minna von Barnhelm. The passage Harden has in mind occurs in Act II, Scene 1, where the maid says to her mistress, "Man spricht selten von der Tugend, die man hat; aber desto öftrer von der, die uns fehlt." ("We seldom talk about virtue we possess, but more often about the virtue we lack.") Warum also soll Herr Bahr, dieses routinirte Nichts, nicht von „Empfindung“ und „Leidenschaft“ schwärmen und die Routine verdammen? Dabei ist nichts zu verwundern. Franziska,Franziska is the name of Minna's maid in Lessing's Minna von Barnhelm. noch besser Dortchen LakenreißerDortchen Lakenreißer is the German equivalent of Doll Tearsheet in the translation of Shakespeare's Henry IV, Part II by August Wilhelm Schlegel (1867-1845). hat ihn charakterisirt. („Weil Ihr einer armen Hure u.s.w.“)The passage indicated by Harden, from Henry IV, Part II, Act II, Scene 4, lines 1398-1406, is Doll Tearsheet's response to Mistress Quickly's use of the title "captain" in reference to the scoundrel Pistol:
Doll Tearsheet. Captain! thou abominable damned cheater, art thou not ashamed / to be called captain? An captains were of my mind, they would / truncheon you out, for taking their names upon you before you / have earned them. You a captain! you slave, for what? for tearing / a poor whore's ruff in a bawdy-house? He a captain! hang him, / rogue! he lives upon mouldy stewed prunes and dried cakes. A / captain! God's light, these villains will make the word as odious / as the word "occupy;" which was an excellent good word before it / was ill sorted: therefore captains had need look to't.
Ich fürchte, ich werde Ihrem ArtikelThe article in question is uncertain. nicht leicht Raum schaffen können. Wenn Sie aber die Güte haben, ihn zu senden, will ich Ihnen gleich meine Ansicht sagen

tei:closer.tei:salute: Mit besten Grüßen aus qualvoller Hitze

tei:div.tei:p: Minna's chambermaid says that people most enjoy talking about qualities they don't possess. So why shouldn't Herr Bahr, that proficient non-entity, extol "sensibility" and "passion" and condemn proficiency? There is nothing remarkable in it. Franziska, or even better, Doll Tearsheet sketched his character well. ("For [...] a poor whore's etc.")
I'm afraid I won't easily be able to make space for your article. If you would be so kind as to send it, however, I will give you my opinion straight away.

tei:closer.tei:salute: With best regards from the depths of distraction,
